author: tefera
title: Port BrightID
description: Despite the promise of self sovereign identity most implementations depend on centralized verification and are not user friendly.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of ​​this proposal is a bit confusing... but as I understand it, it boils down to adding Atala Prism to an existing decentralized recognition system called BrightID. This system is based on a familiar recognition, which analyzes the interaction of users online and offline. How is this possible? I would like the proponents to better define how this tool works and in terms that are understandable to all readers. The BrightID system is said to be based on Etherioum (is it an Ethereum-turned cryptocurrency?). Something that worries me a bit here is this: "the only thing needed to authenticate a person's uniqueness is an image and a name that can be changed at any time". How does this system guarantee that your information is inviolable, since it is so simple to define the identity of its users? I also think I'm not very clear on how this junction of BrightID and DIDs would be. Would people using BrightID automatically have DIDs generated? This couldn't be an involuntary process, right? How would this adoption take place, how would the explanation be made about what Atala Prism is, how to convince these people of the advantages of having a decentralized identity also in Cardano, since they would already have another one? The authors of the proposal justify that this solution would be interesting for cases in which populations have suffered from disasters (generated by natural or human causes). But why, exactly? The authors have one of these examples (https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Decentralized-Autonomous-Iddir/381135-48088), which is very positive, but even reading this proposal I cannot understand how this new BrightID + Atala Prism functionality would be utilized. In general: several doubts arose when I read the proposal, I don't think it was possible to fully understand its impact on the Cardano ecosystem. However, I believe that yes, it could be something very interesting and that would align well with the objectives of the challenge if the proposal were described in a simpler way and answering the doubts that I pointed out here (maybe other CAs have other questions or even the same ones).
f6_assessments.q1: Little is said about the team that makes up this project. There are 3 authors, but the information mentioned in "relevant experience" seems to me to say about only one person... I would like to know what ITN is (in "Run ITN"). I think this proposal lacked a more adequate presentation of the members, understanding: their names, what they have done so far, areas of academic training and professional performance and especially how they relate to the Cardano ecosystem and Atala Prism. The team that proposed this idea is the same team that developed the BrightID platform, right? This gives us a certain security about the capacity of their work, but in no way, unfortunately, guarantees us that they have knowledge and experience in Cardano and understand well about Atala Prism. Therefore, I do not believe that much confidence is passed in the team to properly execute the proposal. About a roadmap, it doesn't exist here, unfortunately, the authors were careless and did not explain at any time what activities would be developed in order to achieve the final result (the integration between their platform and Atala Prism). It is essential to have a timeline of activities to understand the development process, who would do what and so on. And as for financing, it is all geared towards paying the professionals involved, at a cost of USD 30 per hour (a very fair amount, in my opinion). Is it possible to partially understand where the money goes, since it is not defined how many hours each professional would work (it would be 100 hours for each, since there are 3 people)? When they say that the value would change with the input of the developers, why, and how much would it be? I believe that we still have a number of open questions about how the money would be used, that is, it is necessary to give a more detailed explanation of this. Unfortunately, therefore, both in terms of staff, script and budget are superficial and need a lot of improvement.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately, this is the most incomplete part of the proposal. The authors spend most of their time describing what BrightID is, but they don't map out a roadmap, as I mentioned in the previous topic, and they don't define KPIs either. Thus, no information is provided on how we could follow the development process of this project; also, with the absence of KPIs, nothing is defined that can be tracked as partial/final results. Without such information, the proposal is not auditable. I suggest that the authors develop these two things (a detailed roadmap and KPIs), and from that establish a direct and frequent contact with the Cardano community, so that it is possible to verify if what was promised is being fulfilled. I think it would also be interesting to do a user survey. Those who already use the BrightID platform made their DIDs in Atala Prism, and if so, what did you think? Have their expectations been met, have they been interested in our blockchain to the point of getting involved with other ecosystem activities? This is just a qualitative suggestion. In addition, you need to define numbers: how many people have acquired DIDs, how this number grows, according to the passage of time, etc etc.

f6_assessments.q0: Proposal identifies the problem of depending on centralized entities to create identity for oneself. Porting BrightID with the Cardano ecosystem will ad value by bringing a lot of new identities to the ecosystem. They haven't provided any metrics so it's hard to see if they align with the Challenge. The metrics for this kind of project is not hard to imagine and they may very well be much aligned with the challenge. In order to win the trust of voters you need to provide all the info that is expected of you. This kind of project will be able to scale well as identity is an absolute must going forward.
f6_assessments.q1: No proof of relevant skills or team is given. The voters need to know your background and abilities in order to trust you with this project. The budget is still unclear as they  mention it will change with input from developers. Right now it only states 300 hours of work needs to be compensated. No launch date has been provided. A Launch date is essential, because it shows commitment and aim. They have explained how BrightID works, but not how they will port it. No technical details are provided. This info is needed to show voters how you  plan to approach this problem. It also reveals your technical abilities and can boost voter trust. They haven't considered any risks. Not being aware and prepared for future risks will slow you down.
f6_assessments.q2: No roadmap with milestones or KPIs have been provided. Without this info it is very hard to track the progress and performance of this project. You have to show how you plan to execute this project on a timetable and provide KPIs so that the community can track your project. They identify the problem of going through centralized entities to create identity for oneself and they plan to solve it by porting an existing product to the Cardano blockchain. The way it will be ported is still very unclear.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a nice and possible solution because BrightID is already based on Etherium and has proven its success. So porting this tool to Cardano not only would complement Atala Prism and accelerate mass decentralized identity (DID) adoption but also promises to be successful.
f6_assessments.q1: The relavant experience is poor demontrated (there is no attachment to prove or no more demonstrate than just listing). There is also no detail plan that what he/she will do (in phases/milestones).
f6_assessments.q2: We can see if they complete porting BrightID to Cardano or not but the proposal still need to have key metrics/ KPIs to measure the expected outcome.

f6_assessments.q0:
While BrightID might look like a promising start in the DID process, I find their concept raises too many questions that I haven’t been able to find the answers to, neither on their website nor on their other social platforms. Building a DID technology based on a zoom conference meeting and selection of connections is very intrusive and inefficient.
Porting successful platforms from ETH to speed up the development of ATALA Prism and DID on Cardano is a very good idea if well implemented, though I’m not sure if this one is suitable and no other better tool will come along in the near future.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have not provided any external links or description of their prior experience and skills, so it’s hard to assess their capabilities in implementing this proposal, especially since they write “This will change with input from developers” meaning they are not the ones developing the port.
The plan lacks many details, it contains a lot of copy-pasted information from the BrightID website, but not much about the process of porting it from ETH to Cardano.
f6_assessments.q2: As I have stated in the above assessments, the proposal lacks a lot of information, like an estimated launch date, a roadmap, KPIs and all the other items from the self-assessment checklist, that are not needed to be listed here again. Without these, the community cannot properly evaluate the process and success of the project.

solution: BrightID allows Individuals to prove uniqueness through social connections starting from family, without the need for centralized service.
experience: Opensource localization initiator, coordinator and translator. Community organizer. Run ITN, Catalyst member since Fund1, CA, vCA
